title: Getting Started with Data Analysis
text:
Welcome to this example post! This demonstrates a well-structured blog post with multiple sections, code examples, and engaging content.
Data analysis is a crucial skill in today’s data-driven world. Whether you’re working with scientific research, business intelligence, or exploring personal projects, understanding how to effectively analyze data can unlock valuable insights.

title: Getting Started with Data Analysis
text:
Welcome to this example post! This demonstrates a well-structured blog post with multiple sections, code examples, and engaging content.
Data analysis is a crucial skill in today’s data-driven world. Whether you’re working with scientific research, business intelligence, or exploring personal projects, understanding how to effectively analyze data can unlock valuable insights.

title: Getting Started with Data Analysis
text:
Key Concepts

Data Collection
The first step in any data analysis project is collecting your data. This can come from various sources:

Public datasets: Government databases, research repositories, or open data platforms
Surveys: Direct data collection through questionnaires
APIs: Programmatic access to data services
Web scraping: Extracting data from websites (with proper permissions)



Data Cleaning
Before you can analyze your data, you need to ensure it’s clean and ready for analysis:

Remove duplicates: Eliminate redundant entries
Handle missing values: Decide on appropriate strategies (imputation, removal, etc.)
Standardize formats: Ensure consistent data types and formats
Validate data: Check for outliers and inconsistencies



Exploratory Data Analysis
Once your data is clean, exploratory data analysis (EDA) helps you understand the patterns and relationships in your data:
import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Load your data
df = pd.read_csv('data.csv')

# Basic statistics
print(df.describe())

# Visualize distributions
df.hist(figsize=(10, 6))
plt.show()

title: Getting Started with Data Analysis
text:
Best Practices
When conducting data analysis, keep these best practices in mind:

Document your process: Keep track of all transformations and decisions
Version control: Use tools like Git to track changes to your analysis
Reproducibility: Ensure others can replicate your results
Ethical considerations: Respect privacy and data usage agreements

title: Getting Started with Data Analysis
text:
Conclusion
Data analysis is both an art and a science. With practice and the right tools, you can extract meaningful insights from even the most complex datasets. Remember to start simple, document everything, and always question your assumptions.
Happy analyzing!

title: LittleMonkeyBlog
text:
Welcome to LittleMonkeyBlog! This is a space for exploring ideas, sharing insights, and documenting interesting discoveries.
Browse through the posts below to find topics that interest you. You can filter by category or use the search functionality to find specific content. Each post includes detailed information, code examples, and practical insights.

title: LittleMonkeyBlog
text:
Recent Posts
The listing below shows all available posts, sorted by date with the most recent first. Click on any post to read the full content.

title: Quick Start Guide
text:
python3 new_post.py "Your Post Title"



quarto preview
Then open http://localhost:4200 in your browser.



git add .
git commit -m "Add new post"
git push origin main
GitHub Actions will automatically deploy it!



Press Cmd+Shift+P (Mac) or Ctrl+Shift+P (Windows/Linux), then:

“Create New Blog Post” - Create a new post (prompts for title)
“Preview Blog (Local)” - Start local preview server
“Render Blog” - Build the site
“Quick Publish (Render + Push)” - One-step publish




Each post lives in posts/[slug]/index.qmd with this structure:
---
title: "Your Title"
date: "YYYY-MM-DD"
categories: [Category1, Category2]
description: "Brief description"
---




Use new_post.py to create posts with proper structure
Preview before pushing to catch errors early
Posts auto-deploy on push to main
Check .cursor/instructions.md for detailed workflow
